title: The Murder at Blackwood Hall
invitation:
To Mr. Sherlock Holmes,
221B Baker Street,
London.

Dear Mr. Holmes,

I find myself in need of your unique talents once again. A most perplexing and troubling case has arisen at Blackwood Hall, the estate of the late Sir Reginald Blackwood. Last night, Sir Reginald was found dead in his study, stabbed with one of his own ceremonial daggers. The door was locked from the inside, and the window was bolted shut—an impossible crime, by all accounts.

The family and guests are in a state of agitation, and the staff whisper of curses and phantoms. I fear that without your keen eye and deductive reasoning, this case may remain unsolved.

I have secured your invitation to Blackwood Hall. A carriage will collect you and Dr. Watson at your earliest convenience. Time is of the essence, as a storm threatens to cut off the estate from the outside world.

Yours sincerely,
Inspector G. Lestrade, Scotland Yard
description:
The case of The Murder at Blackwood Hall is full of mystery and dark secrets. The mansion feels alive, with shadowy hallways and hidden rooms that whisper tales of the past. Sir Reginald Blackwood, a wealthy and powerful man, has been killed in his own Study. The door was locked from the inside, and the window was bolted shut—making it seem impossible for the killer to enter or exit.

The suspects are as puzzling as the crime:
Lady Eleanor Blackwood, Sir Reginald’s wife, whose calm demeanor belies her inner coldness and the fortune she stands to inherit.
Victor Blackwood, Sir Reginald’s estranged son, an artist with a volatile temper and a history of clashes with his father over money and lifestyle.
Miss Clara Hastings, Sir Reginald’s niece, quiet and polite, yet her hidden plans make her hard to read.
Dr. Jonathan Graves, the family doctor, whose nervous behavior and odd disappearance at times raise suspicion.
Mr. Harold Whitaker, Sir Reginald’s business partner, embroiled in financial disputes and a crumpled contract of dubious nature.
Mrs. Beatrice Poole, the long-serving housekeeper, keeper of family secrets and witness to muddy footprints outside the Study window.

suspects.name: LadyEleanorBlackwood
suspects.statement: I was in my room at the time of the murder, preparing for the ball. My maid left shortly after, and I heard nothing unusual. I have no motive to harm my husband.
suspects.clue: A torn, partially burned love letter addressed to Sir Reginald found in the fireplace.

suspects.name: VictorBlackwood
suspects.statement: I admit I was near the Study to confront my father about money. However, I left immediately after my argument. I have no desire to commit murder.
suspects.clue: Paint-stained gloves found in my room and a smear of paint on the study's doorknob.

suspects.name: MissClaraHastings
suspects.statement: I took the key to the Study that evening because I was worried about my uncle's safety, but I swear I did not kill him. I was deeply upset and broke down in tears.
suspects.clue: A key to the Study found hidden in my diary.

suspects.name: DrJonathanGraves
suspects.statement: I was in the Drawing Room when the murder occurred. When asked about a vial of poison in my bag, I became very nervous—though it was only for medical research.
suspects.clue: A vial of poison discovered in my medical bag.

suspects.name: MrHaroldWhitaker
suspects.statement: I was at Blackwood Hall to discuss urgent business matters with Sir Reginald. I had no part in his death and will not comment further on my business contracts.
suspects.clue: A crumpled business contract with Sir Reginald's signature found in my coat pocket.

suspects.name: MrsBeatricePoole
suspects.statement: I was in the kitchen all evening preparing dinner. I only noticed muddy footprints outside the Study window later on, but I cannot explain them.
suspects.clue: Muddy footprints matching my shoes found outside the Study window.

rooms.name: Foyer
rooms.description: You are standing in the Grand Foyer of Blackwood Hall, a cavernous entry with towering ceilings. A massive crystal chandelier illuminates the checkered marble floor. Portraits of the Blackwood family line the walls, their eyes following your every move.

rooms.name: DiningHall
rooms.description: You step into the Dining Hall. The long table is set with fine china, and faded tapestries depict hunting scenes. A candelabra casts a soft glow over the room.

objects.name: boots
objects.description: Muddy leather boots with distinct tread patterns sit by the door.
objects.examine: Muddy boots rest by the door, their tread patterned with deep grooves. Fresh soil clings to the soles.
objects.deduce: The tread pattern matches footprints outside the Study window.

objects.name: contract
objects.description: A crumpled business contract lies discarded, its terms heavily disputed.
objects.examine: A business contract stamped 'VOID' in red ink. Sir Reginald’s signature crosses out a £20,000 payment to Harold Whitaker.
objects.deduce: The contract was signed by MrHaroldWhitaker and shows financial desperation.

rooms.name: DrawingRoom
rooms.description: You enter the Drawing Room. Plush armchairs and a grand piano are arranged around a fireplace. A bay window offers a view of the overgrown gardens.

rooms.name: Study
rooms.description: You step into the Study—the crime scene. Bookshelves line the walls, and a mahogany desk sits cluttered with papers. Ceremonial daggers hang above the fireplace, but one dagger is conspicuously missing. The drawer has been forced open, and a faint smell of perfume lingers. There is something in the fireplace that is not totally burned. A peculiar paint stain on the doorknob catches your eye.

objects.name: perfume
objects.description: A faint smell of perfume lingers in the air, out of place in a room of death.
objects.examine: A floral aroma lingers near the study door—jasmine and bergamot. The scent grows stronger near Lady Eleanor’s quarters.
objects.deduce: The perfume matches Lady Eleanor’s signature scent, but why would she leave such an obvious trace?

objects.name: letter
objects.description: A partially burned letter in the fireplace reveals traces of passionate handwriting.
objects.examine: A charred letter fragment bears the words: '...forgive me… your father will never accept us…' The ink is faded, the paper brittle.
objects.deduce: The letter was written by Lady Eleanor, but the signature was burned intentionally.

objects.name: compartment
objects.description: A small hidden compartment in the desk remains locked, hinting at concealed secrets.
objects.examine: A hairline seam disrupts the desk’s mahogany veneer. A tiny keyhole glints under the lamplight.
objects.deduce: The compartment contains a key matching Clara’s diary sketch.

objects.name: statue
objects.description: A bronze statue with a subtle handle mechanism stands between books on the shelf.
objects.examine: A bronze falcon perches on the shelf, its wings spread mid-flight. The base is worn smooth, as if frequently handled.
objects.deduce: The statue’s mechanism opens the hidden passage in the Library.

objects.name: doorknob
objects.description: A peculiar paint stain on the doorknob catches your eye.
objects.examine: A brass doorknob smeared with dried blue paint.
objects.deduce: The paint matches Victor’s gloves, indicating he was in the Study.

rooms.name: Library
rooms.description: You enter the Library, a two-story room filled with books. A wrought-iron balcony runs along the upper level, and a spiral staircase leads up to the Turret Room.

rooms.name: SecondFloorHallway
rooms.description: Climbing the grand staircase from the Grand Foyer, you reach the second floor. The hallway is lined with doors: Lady Eleanor’s room is the first on the left, Victor’s room is on the right, and at the far end, Clara’s room is on the left. A narrow staircase leads up to the Turret Room.

rooms.name: TurretRoom
rooms.description: You are in the Turret Room. Dusty, old furniture fills the circular space, and a cracked window offers a panoramic view of the estate. On the floor, you notice some crumpled papers that emit a strong and pungent smell. They seem significant.

objects.name: pills
objects.description: A pile of crumpled papers emits a strong and pungent smell.
objects.examine: A small glass vial labeled 'Morphine.'. Half the pills are missing.
objects.deduce: These sleeping bills were used to drug Sir Reginald before the murder.

rooms.name: LadyEleanorRoom
rooms.description: Lady Eleanor’s room is opulent, with lavish décor and rich fabrics.

rooms.name: VictorRoom
rooms.description: Victor’s room is chaotic, with scattered canvases and paint-stained furnishings.

objects.name: gloves
objects.description: Paint-stained gloves lie discarded near an easel.
objects.examine: Paint-stained gloves lie discarded, the fingertips worn thin. Blue oil pigment cakes the seams.
objects.deduce: The paint matches the stain on the Study’s doorknob.

rooms.name: ClaraRoom
rooms.description: Clara’s room is simple and modest, with minimal furnishings and a calm atmosphere.

objects.name: diary
objects.description: A leather-bound diary lies open, revealing a sketch of a small key.
objects.examine: A leather-bound diary lies open, revealing a sketch of a small key. The pages are marked with dates from the past week.
objects.deduce: The key sketch matches the hidden compartment in the Study.

finalExam.question: How did the killer leave the locked room?
Who benefits financially the most if Sir Reginald dies?
Where was the murder weapon hidden?
Who helped Lady Eleanor commit the crime?

Search other rooms for additional clues and objects.

Add important clues to your journal using 'journal add [note]'.
Review your collected clues with the 'journal' command.
Ask Dr. Watson for hints using 'ask watson'.
Solve the case by answering the final exam questions ('final exam').
watsonHints: Look for inconsistencies in the suspect statements.
The location of evidence is key.
Sometimes, the smallest detail reveals the truth.
